msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Leviticus 13
ab.l: And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,

‘When a man
shall have a sore or a swelling or
a spot in the skin of his body, and it becomes a disease
of leprosy, and he shall be brought to Aaron the priest or
to one of his sons the priests,

And
the priest shall look on the disease in the skin of the body,
and hair in the disease will have turned white, and the disease’s appearance
is deeper than the skin of his body, it is a disease of leprosy.
And the priest shall look on him, and shall pronounce him unclean.

And if it is a white spot in the skin of his body, and
its appearance is not deeper than the skin, and its hair
has not turned white, the priest shall shut up the disease
for seven days.

And the priest shall look on him the seventh day,
and, lo, if the disease in its sight stayed |unchanged|, and
the disease has not spread in the skin, the priest shall shut him up seven days
a second time.

And the priest shall look on him
the seventh day a second time, and, lo, if the disease has faded,
and the disease has not spread in the skin, the priest shall pronounce him clean.
It is a disease called “scab”, and
he shall wash his clothes, and he will be clean.

But if
the scab spreads much in the skin after he has shown himself
to the priest, after his cleansing, he shall show himself to the priest
a second time.

And the priest shall see, and, lo,
if the scab has spread in the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean.
It is a leprosy.

When the disease of leprosy is in a man,
then he shall be brought to the priest.

And the priest shall look,
and, lo, if there is a swelling appearing white in the skin, and it turned
the hair white, and there is an efflorescence of raw flesh in the swelling:

It is an aging leprosy in the skin of his body, and the priest shall pronounce him unclean,
and shall not shut him up, for he is unclean.

And if
a leprosy, indeed, breaks out in the skin, and the leprosy covers
all the skin of |one with| the disease from his head even to his foot,
to wherever it is within sight of the priest’s eyes,

Then the priest shall look, and, lo, if the leprosy has covered all
his body, he shall pronounce clean |the one with| the disease: it has all
changed and turned white. He is clean.

And on the day
the raw flesh appears on him, he shall be unclean.

And the priest shall look
on the raw flesh, and pronounce him unclean. The raw flesh
is unclean. It is leprosy.

Or if the raw goes back again and turns
to white, he shall come to the priest,

And
the priest shall see him: and, lo, if the disease is turned
to white, the priest shall pronounce clean |the one with| the disease.
He is clean.

And if there is a body
in the skin of which there is an abscess, and it heals,

And
in the place of the boil there is a swelling appearing white or a white spot
appearing red|dish|, and it is shown to the priest,

The priest shall look, and, lo, it its appearance is lower than the skin,
and its hair has changed and turned white, the priest shall pronounce him unclean.
It is a disease of leprosy. It spread with the boil.

But if the priest sees him, and, lo, there is no white hair in it,
and if it is not lower than the skin and has faded, the
priest shall shut him up seven days.

And if it spreads
much in the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean. It is a disease.

But if the spot remains in one place
and does not spread, it is a burning abscess, and the priest shall pronounce him clean.

Or if there is any body in the skin of which
there is a burn from a fire, and the efflorescence of the burn is a white
spot, appearing red|dish| or white,

And the priest shall look on it,
and, lo, if the hair in the spot has turned white and
its appearance is deeper than the skin, it is a leprosy
spread with the burn, and the priest shall pronounce him unclean. It is the disease
of leprosy.

And if the priest sees it,
and, lo, there is no white hair in the spot and it is no deeper
than the skin and has faded, the priest shall shut him up
seven days.

And the priest shall look on him the seventh day:
if it is spread much in the skin, the priest shall pronounce him unclean.
It is the disease of leprosy.

And if
the spot stays in its place and does not spread in the skin and has faded,
it is a swelling of the sore, and the priest shall pronounce him clean.
It is a burn from the sore.

And when a man or woman
has a disease on the head or the beard,

And the priest shall look on the disease, and, lo, if its appearance
is deeper than the skin and there is in it bright thin hair,
the priest shall pronounce him unclean. It is a scab, a leprosy of the head
or the beard.

And if the priest sees
the disease of the scab, and, lo, its appearance is no
deeper than the skin and that there is no black hair in it,
then the priest shall shut up |the one with| the disease of the scab seven days.

And on the seventh day the priest shall look on the disease,
and, lo, if the scab does not spread, and there is no
bright hair in it, and the appearance of the scab is not deeper
than the skin:

And he shall shave himself, but the scab
he shall not shave, and the priest shall shut up |the one with| the scab seven days
a second time.

And the priest shall look on
the scab on the seventh day, and, lo, if the scab has not spread
in the skin, and its appearance is not deeper than the skin,
the priest shall pronounce him clean. And he shall wash his clothes
and will be clean.

But if the scab spreads much
in the skin after his cleansing:

And the priest shall look on him,
and, lo, if the scab has spread in the skin, the priest shall not inspect
for the bright hair. He is unclean.

And if
the scab in its sight stayed |the same|, and black hair has grown in it,
the scab is healed. He is clean. And the priest shall pronounce him clean.

And if a man or a woman has
spots, white spots in the skin of their bodies:

And the priest shall look,
and, lo, in the skin of their bodies there are dim spots
appearing white in the skin, it is a disease called bohaq that has spread
on the body. He is clean.

And if a man’s head is gone bald,
he is called qereaḥ. He is clean.

And
if a man’s head becomes bald from the edge of his face, he is called gibeaḥ.
He is clean.

And if there is on the back
of his head or on the front of his head a white disease appearing red|dish|,
it is a leprosy spreading on the back of his head or on the front
of his head.

And the priest shall look on it, and, lo,
if the swelling of the disease appears red|dish| white on the back of his head
or on the front of his head, like the appearance of leprosy in the skin
of the body:

He is a leprous man. He is unclean.
The priest shall pronounce him unclean.
His disease is in his head.

And the leprous |man| in whom
the disease is: his clothes shall be ripped, and his head shall be
bare, and he shall cover over his moustache, and shall cry out, “Unclean, unclean!”, so that those who walk that way may take heed.

All the days in which the disease shall be in him
he shall be unclean. He is unclean. He shall dwell alone.
His place of dwelling shall be outside the camp.

And the garment: if there is
the disease of leprosy in it — in garment of wool or
in garment of linen,

Either in the warp or in the woof
of the linen or of the wool or in leather or in any
item made of leather —

And if the disease is greenish
or reddish in the garment or in the leather, either
in the warp or in the woof, or in any item of leather:
it is a disease of leprosy and it shall be shown to the priest.

And the priest shall look on the disease, and shut in
the disease seven days.

And the priest shall see the
disease on the seventh day: if the disease has spread
in the garment, either in the warp or in the woof, or
in the leather, whatever is the use of the leather,
the disease is a terminal leprosy. It is unclean.

And
he shall therefore burn that garment or the warp or
the woof either in the wool or in the linen or
any leather item in which the disease is, because
it is a terminal leprosy. It shall be burned in fire.

And if the priest sees it, and, lo, the disease has not spread
in the garment, either in the warp or in the woof, or
in any leather item,

Then the priest shall command, and
they shall wash that in which is the disease, and he shall shut it in seven days
a second time.

And the priest shall look after
the thing has been washed from the disease, and, lo, the disease has not changed
its appearance, and the disease has not spread, it is unclean.
You shall burn it in the fire. It is a disease called peḥetet,
on the back or on the front.

And if the priest sees it,
and, lo, the disease has faded after it was washed,
he shall rip it from the garment or from the leather or
from the warp or from the woof.

And if it still appears
in the garment, either in the warp or in the woof, or
in any leather item, it is a spreading leprosy.
You shall burn in fire that in which the disease is.

And
the garment, either warp or woof, or
any leather item which you shall wash: if the disease departs from it,
it shall be washed a second time, and will be clean.’

This is the teaching of the disease of leprosy
of a garment of wool or linen or warp
or woof or any leather item,
to pronounce it clean or to pronounce it unclean.

app.note: K: sore of the sore; a scribal error (or a mistranslation), cf. Heb. שְׂאֵת הַמִּכְוָה ‘a swelling of the burn’.

Heb. בֹּהַק ‘a kind of disease’ (Klein 1987: 65), ‘harmless eruption of the skin, skin-disease’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 111). | Translated as ‘freckled spot’ in KJ2000, as ‘leukoderma’ in ESV, as ‘tetter’ by Friedman (2003). | EKar. bohaq in C is translated as ‘freckled spot’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 146).
K: sore; a scribal error (or a mistranslation), cf. Heb. שְׂאֵת ‘the swelling’.
